definition: to make into/to change into/-ization/to ... -ize/to transform/abbr. for 化學|化学[hua4 xue2]

sentences.english: Indeed, Japan is good example of how such subcultures come about.
sentences.chinese: 有关移动电话亚文化的产生，日本确实是一个好例子。

sentences.english: The sub-culture of the polytheism is one of the main sources of the precedent.
sentences.chinese: 多神教亚文化是先例现象的主要来源之一。

sentences.english: Zhang assured that the average viewer's taste has not stooped to a new low.
sentences.chinese: 张志华确信观众不会奉迎新生的亚文化。

sentences.english: Third is the conflict between equal rural culture and biased urban sub-culture.
sentences.chinese: 三是平等的乡村文化，与歧视性的城市亚文化的冲突。

sentences.english: They tend to drift into work subcultures.
sentences.chinese: 他们倾向于流入工作的亚文化领域。

sentences.english: Because of this the otaku subculture has much influence over the mainstream anime industry in Japan.
sentences.chinese: 因此御宅族亚文化对日本主流动画产业有巨大影响。

sentences.english: Tattoo of youngsters is the reflection of sub-cultural phenomenon.
sentences.chinese: 现今青少年的文身是一种亚文化现象的反映。

definition: minority of the population/non-mainstream (activity, pursuit etc)/niche (market etc)
spoofing culture (Web-based genre in PRC acquiring cult status from 2005, involving humorous, satirical or fantastical videos, photo collections, texts, poems etc)
otaku, a Japanese term for people with obsessive interests such as anime, manga, and video games/see also 宅男[zhai2 nan2]/see also 宅女[zhai2 nu:3]
(loanword) kitsch, in a sense that originates in the writing of Milan Kundera: getting emotional about sth due to the influence of social conditioning
two-dimensional/the fictional worlds of anime, comics and games
